RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 29 March 2019: Kudlow calls on Fed to cut rates 50bps
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

US MARKET WRAP 29 March 2019: Kudlow calls on Fed to cut rates 50bps

 

* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar up/flat, Treasuries down, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Kudlow calls on Fed to cut rates 50bps; MV3 rejected.

* NEXT WEEK: Japanese Tankan; Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI; Spanish, Italian, French, German, UK, EZ & US Manufacturing PMI; US Retail Sales & Business Inventories; ECB’s de Guindos; BoC’s Poloz; Earnings from Walgreens Boots Alliance. Note: UK Clocks move forward 1 hour on Sunday, CDT-BST time gap of 6 hours returns.

* FED: NEC Director Kudlow told Axios that the Fed should "immediately" cut rates by 50bps, echoing comments from Fed Board of Governors Nominee Stephen Moore this week; Axios noted that it was the first time a White House official publicly called on the central bank to take action on rates. In an interview with CNBC, Kudlow seemed to intimate that these were Trump’s views. Policymakers have been suggesting that the recent inversion of the 3m/10yr curve is not a harbinger of a future recession. Indeed, many have offered the argument that other factors might be in play, such as the size of the Fed’s balance sheet, which distorts the signal presented by the yield curve. That argument was alluded to by Fed’s Quarles (voter) and Kaplan (non-voter) on Friday, echoing what we have recently heard from the likes of the Fed’s Williams (voter) and Daly (non-voter). While policymakers are genuinely confident that the US economy is in good shape, Fed’s Kashkari (non-voter) suggested that he now sees elevated chances of a recession, even though it is not his base case. Analysts have noted that, with the Fed likely to tolerate an overshoot in inflation, the focus of data will be on the growth and activity metrics (PMIs and ISM next week could give us some insight, while labour market metrics will also be eyed, making next week’s payrolls report, once again, one of the main features of the week).

* TRADE: After sentiment was buoyed in the early European morning by positive trade talk comments by Treasury secretary Mnuchin, there were scant updates from the Far-East besides a cursory reference made by Xinhua stating that China-US trade talks have made “new” progress. This renewed positivity came after yesterday nights good vibes from the Beijing talks, with talks set to resume in Washington on Monday. Expectations were tempered marginally, however, after Hu Xijin of the China Global Times stated that the Chinese delegation is more cautious on its optimism than the US. More downside risk was also added by the US President who stated that he may close the US-Mexico border and stop trade if the Central American country don’t stop illegal immigration, which saw weakness in the MXN on renewed American tensions.

* US PERSONAL INCOME, SPENDING, PCE: Friday’s personal income & spending data release was abnormal due to the overhang from the government shutdown, the report combined January’s income and spending, and gave just the income section for February. February personal income rose by +0.2%, up from January’s -0.1% fall, but shy of the expected +0.3%. The core PCE index for January showed an increase of 0.1%, also beneath the expected 0.2% which would have been unchanged from December; the PCE deflator missed expectations too and printed a fall of -0.1%, “Both measures indicate sub-2% annual inflation and give the Fed more reason to pause,” analysts at Wells Fargo Economics comment, making their case for the figures complementing the weaker domestic demand narrative spawned from this week’s export/import data, which showed falling imports. Following the ominous -0.6% nosedive in consumer spending in December, expectations were set for a modest reversal at +0.3% in January, however spending grew by a meagre +0.1%, hinting that December’s data wasn’t necessarily a fluke as some had hypothesised. Wells’ analysts provide the succinct summary, “the consumer is losing momentum.”

* CANADIAN GDP: Canadian monthly GDP rose by more than expected in January (0.3% MM vs 0.0% exp.), with ten of the eleven major industrial sectors seeing expansion. On the other side of the coin, mining and O&G extraction contracted, given the Government-mandated production cuts in Alberta. "With a strong rebound in January GDP, Q1-2019 nowcast is at 1.09% Q/Q SAAR," Scotiabank's analysts said. "The monthly pattern in industry-level GDP underlying this nowcast is -0.1% and +0.1% in February and March. Barring negative surprises in February and March, Q1-2019 should support the Bank of Canada in resuming rate hikes some time this year."

* US NEW HOME SALES: 667k reported vs 620k expected. Housing data is seen improving as ease from highs seen in Q4. "New home sales have been tracking the mortgage applications data with a lag of about three months, and these data continue that pattern," Pantheon Macroeconomics writes. "The mortgage data point to broadly steady next few months." The economic consultancy notes that new home sales have outperformed existing sales over the last year, "perhaps because a much smaller proportion of new sales take place in the high-tax states of the north east and elsewhere,£ Pantheon believes, adding that "the capping of state and local tax deductions last year appears to have caused chaos in the existing home market in these areas, on a big enough scale to depress the national numbers quite sharply." Pantheon adds that this "triggered a market narrative that housing is in real trouble, but that view clearly is contradicted by the new home sales numbers." The consultancy expects housing investment to make a positive contribution to Q2 GDP numbers, perhaps even Q1 too.

* BREXIT: UK MPs voted by a margin of 58 (344 vs 286) to reject PM May’s Withdrawal Agreement. In light of the rejection, the EU exit date becomes 12 April (vs 23 May, should it have been accepted). European Council President Tusk called an emergency EU summit on 10 April in light of the rejection, with the UK needing to explain its Brexit Plan B before 8 April, so leaders have time to give consideration (analysts are of the view that the EU would likely grant an extension to the Brexit process, but will want to see the UK present a concrete plan and participate in EU elections). A spokesperson said that it was almost certain the UK would now have to participate in the European election on 23-26 May. Attention shifts to Monday, where further indicative votes are expected, and UK PM May might have to re-think some of her red lines in order to bring some consensus among lawmakers, so she can take unified position to the EU in order to request the extension. Elsewhere, there has been some suggestion that the rejection opens the possibility of a general election; however, an MV4 looks more likely to proceed that, where a No. 10 source said on Friday evening in London that Downing Street is indeed planning to bring UK PM May's deal back to the HoC again next week, and is threatening an election, again, if it cannot secure a majority. Capital Economics says one of four things must happen: either May's deal is passed, the UK will have left the EU without a deal, the UK will have decided to stay in the EU, or another delay to the Brexit process will have been agreed.

* WTI (K9) SETTLES USD 0.84 HIGHER AT USD 60.14/BBL; BRENT (K9) SETTLES USD 0.57 HIGHER AT USD 68.39/BBL. The constructive risk environment, on the back of further trader optimism, saw crude markets setting fresh YTD highs to end the week and quarter. Positive comments out of the Sino-US trade talks in the Asian and European session saw prices rallying into the US equity open, before paring back some of gains as the day progressed with some disappointing US personal income and spending data lurking in the backdrop. Citi's energy analysts said "the market is also gaining supportive press coverage, as newswire coverage touts what will be the largest quarterly rise since 2009, with OPEC+ production cuts and US sanctions on Iran and Venezuela cited as the bullish fundamental lever." Other tailwinds included: Russian Energy Minister Novak denying reports from earlier in the week that Russia would only agree to a three-month extension of supply curbs, which had previously spooked the market; Barclay's forecasting prices to move higher in Q2, with Brent averaging at USD 73/bbl and WTI USD 65/bbl. On the other hand, following Venezuela’s blackout this week, there were signs production was coming back online with news that the Jose oil export terminal had resumed operations. US Baker Hughes Rig Count showed rigs cutting for the sixth consecutive week and the data shows drillers have cut the most rigs in a quarter since 2016, with oil rigs -8 at 816, natgas rigs -2 at 190, total rigs -10 at 1006 for the recent week.

* SPX +0.67% at 2834, NDX +0.80% at 7379, DJI +0.82% at 25929. SECTORS: Energy -0.16%, Materials +0.75%, Industrials +1.01%, Cons Discretionary +0.52%, Cons Staples +0.69%, Healthcare +1.18%, Financials +0.32%, Tech +0.98%, Telecoms +0.29%, Utilities +0.60%.

 

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: DowDuPont (DWDP) traded near the bottom of the Dow on Friday as it guided its earnings and revenue lower due to flooding impact. Restoration Hardware (RH) dived after an abysmal FY profit forecast. 3M (MMM) faced headwinds on a negative mention by JPMorgan’s industrials analyst Tulsa. BlackBerry (BB) surged after reporting its earnings report. Following Thursday’s session seeing all-time highs for Lululemon (LULU), the stock pared back some of the move today as two top stake holders cut their positions. Gilead (GILD) opened higher on reporting its arthritis drug had met its primary endpoint. Celgene (CELG) caught a bid after independent merger review firm ISS gave its approval for it to be acquired by Bristol-Myers (BMY), which consequentially dipped lower. Carmax (KMX) and Science Applications International (SAIC) surged on an earnings beat.

 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLED 9 TICKS LOWER AT 124-07. At settlement, major curve spreads had narrowed by between 1bps (2s5s) and 4bps (2s30s). Profit taking was cited in APAC trade, while the trade optimism chestnut was also cited. An attempt at a move higher in European trade ran out of steam, but did see some upside after PCE data was released (deflator saw the first decline since March 2017). There was also demand inspired by Brexit uncertainty, as well US President Trump firing barbs at Mexico on Twitter, and then subsequently in remarks. The curve remained flatter into the close, and traders will be focussed on Monday’s liquidity impact from SOMA day. 

* GBP: Sterling has been subjected to another wild Brexit related ride within relatively wide ranges of 1.3270-1.2976 in Cable and 0.8650-0.8482 for Eur/Gbp, and looks set to end the week under more intense pressure following the latest Parliament rejection of the WA (which was tabled again without the PD to satisfy the criteria preventing the same motion being presented multiple times). This follows IVs on 8 alternative strategies on Wednesday that failed to a produce a majority backing for any of the amendments, and means the UK is heading for an EU exit on April 12 without any deal or different plan to put before Brussels and argue the case for a further A 50 extension to May 22. Predictably, pressure on PM May to stand down has ramped up amidst GE speculation, but at this point it seems more IVs will take place next week and MV4 is also a possibility. For more please check out our headline feed.

* DXY: The broad Dollar and index are on course to end or at least break a losing streak with net gains on the week, partly due to currency losses elsewhere, a rebound in US Treasury yields amidst a degree of normalisation along the curve from ultra-low and fairly deeply inverted levels. However, the DXY has topped out (for now) at 97.345 vs 96.654 at the start of the week and a 96.404 low after a weak Chicago PMI continued the run of mostly softer than forecast US macro releases.

* EUR: The single currency has lost ground vs the Usd and Chf, in sympathy with the Pound to an extent, and after kicking off the week on the front foot as the latest German Ifo survey beat on all counts, including upward revisions to the previous month. Eur/Usd is currently just above lows only a few pips away from 1.1200 vs 1.1330 or so at one stage, while Eur/Chf is close to the base of 1.1255-1.1163 parameters following more benign Eurozone inflation data, dovish ECB rhetoric on balance and talk of tiered deposits ahead of TLTRO3.

* CAD/NZD/AUD: All ending Friday’s EU session firmer vs their US rival, with the Loonie finding support via encouraging Canadian GDP data that countered a wider trade deficit yesterday, and firmer oil prices. In fact, Usd/Cad is just off a fresh low for the week around 1.3340 after filing bids at 1.3350 vs 1.3450 at the other extreme, and with some additional impetus from China via the lifting of some Canola import restrictions. The Kiwi and Aussie both drew encouragement from reports that more progress was made between the US and China at the latest round of trade negotiations and for the former also improved ANZ consumer sentiment, but Nzd/Usd and Aud/Usd are still rooted closer to the bases of 0.6924-0.6772 and 0.7145-0.7062 respective bands following an unexpectedly dovish twist from the RBNZ (that now sees more chance of the OCR being lowered vs 50-50 between an ease or hike previously), and risks of the RBA following suit next week. Note, however, JPM is now looking for the RBNZ to cut rates twice in May and June, and the Aud/Nzd cross has rebounded from sub-1.0300 to 1.0400+ in response.

* JPY/CHF: The Jpy has been largely hostage to general swings in risk sentiment, UST yields and related Greenback moves as the BoJ stays in full-on easing mode and domestic data remains soft. However, some big option expiries, tech levels and orders for Japanese FY end amidst month and Q1 positioning has also impacted the headline pair plus Jpy crosses. Usd/Jpy has climbed from lows of 109.70 towards 111.00, but is still capped ahead of the next big figure and last Thursday’s 110.96 high, while Eur/Jpy has rebounded over 124.00 having tested and probed below key Fib support around 123.80 on a couple of occasions. Meanwhile, the Franc has been more rangebound between 0.9905-73, but as noted above stronger against the Euro even though the SNB has stressed that NIRP and intervention remains appropriate, if not paramount given the Chf’s high value and the fragility of FX markets.

* NOK/SEK/TRY: The Scandi Crowns have been very volatile within 9.7465-9.6215 and 10.5010-10.3890 ranges vs the Eur amidst fluctuations in crude prices, mixed regional data/surveys and phases of risk aversion/appetite. However, the Nok and Sek retain an underlying bid on comparatively upbeat/hawkish Norges Bank and Riskbank outlooks and policy guidance vs the ECB (and other global Central Banks for that matter). Conversely, the Lira has been largely weaker between 5.7716-5.2680 boundaries vs the Usd as jitters ahead of the weekend regional Turkish elections compounded investor angst over renewed strains on the diplomatic front with the US and a liquidity squeeze induced by the CBRT via the suspension of daily repos.

* COMING-UP: Monday: ISM Mfg, Mfg PMIs, EZ CPI, US Retail Sales, Construction Spending. Tuesday: RBA, EZ Unemployment, US Durable Goods. Wednesday: Services PMI; ISM non-Mfg; China Vice Premier Liu travels to US for trade talks; Aus Trade Balance; US ADP. Thursday: RBI, US Challenger Job Cuts, US and Canadian Labour Market Reports. Friday: No major releases. Click here for full briefing.

* Central Bank Weekly: Previewing RBA, RBI; Reviewing ECB, RBNZ, SARB, Banxico, BCB, NBH. Click here for full briefing.

subject: UK PM May spokesman says the government will continue talks with lawmakers from other parties and discussions with the DUP
US NY Fed Q1 GDP Nowcast unchanged at 1.3%
BREXIT POST-GAME ANALYSIS
content:
*WHAT HAPPENED: UK MPs voted by a majority of 58 (344 vs 286) to reject PM May’s Withdrawal Agreement. In light of the rejection, the EU exit date becomes April 12th, as opposed to the 23rd May should it have been accepted.

*EU REACTION: European Council President Tusks calls an EU summit on April 10th in light of UK Parliament rejected Withdrawal Agreement, with the UK requiring a decision by the 8th of April. The UK then must notify the EU of their decision by the 11th April. The European Commission also admitted that a no-deal Brexit is now the most likely scenario on April 12th.

*PM MAY: The rejection also opens up the possibility for a general election to be called, as suggested by sources cited by HuffPost's Paul Waugh.

*WHAT’S NEXT: Looking ahead, the next step is when the second round of indicative votes will take place, with some suggesting that this could come as soon as Monday 1st April. Henceforth the path will depend on the PM’s acceptance of the results of the indication, should they command any majority at all. It is also worth noting that the indicative vote will need to passage of the Withdrawal Agreement, hence Meaningful Vote 4 cannot be ruled out

subject: BREXIT SITUATION REPORT AND ANALYSIS
content:
*LONG STORY SHORT: The Brexit deal PM May brought forth is essentially made up of two parts, the Withdrawal agreement (which sets out the terms of the UK's departure from the EU) and the Political Declaration (which outlines the shape of future UK-EU relations). To get around House Speaker Bercow’s requirements of a “changed” deal to be put for a third vote, PM May decided to split the deal and only vote on the first part, i.e. the WA. 

*TODAY’S SCHEDULE [GMT]

  • 14:30 – Vote on the Withdrawal Agreement

*AMENDMENTS: House Speaker Bercow has selected no amendments for debate in Parliament today

*WHAT PM MAY NEEDS

NUMBERS: For PM May to get majority for her deal, she needs to:

  • Retain all 242 existing votes
  • Win over all 75 opponents in her own party, including 69 Brexiteers (5 already indicated they will oppose it, one Tory MP abstained from MV2, a vote which could give PM a majority of 2)
  • For every Tory MP who opposes the deal, PM May needs one MP from another party or two opponents willing to abstain

Total excludes the 4 tellers, 3 deputy speakers, 7 Sinn Fein MPs

*WHAT IS EXPECTED:

  • PM May is expected to again be defeated in Parliament as she is unlikely to conjure up support from Labour and DUP (who have confirmed they will vote against the WA). There is still no confirmed direction from the ERG, although the group has said that they are likely to follow the DUP’s lead.
  • Cabinet sources have also noted that the WA is unlikely to pass as there is not enough time to get the votes.
  • MPs claim that just 12 hardcore Tory ERG MPs are left opposing PM May's deal; according to Sun's Deputy Political Editor Steve Hawkes
  • A UK Minister reportedly believes that PM May's WA will be voted down by 20 votes; according to Mail on Sunday's Deputy Political Editor Cole
  • Former Brexit Minister Raab confirms he will vote in favour of PM May's deal
  • SNP's Gray says some Labour MP's are preparing to back PM May's agreement
  • Many more Labour MPs will vote for PM May's Withdrawal Agreement; according to ITV's Preston citing a senior Tory's Whip
  • Buzzfeed's Alex Wickham notes that 45 Tory MPs still oppose PM May's deal
  • UK DUP spokesperson noted that there are ways to pile pressure on PM May's government if the Withdrawal Agreement is passed

*EU EXPECTATIONS: There is little expectation in the EU today that the Withdrawal Agreement will pass and as such, the EU mood is one of resignation now, according to BBC's Adler

*WHAT HAPPENS NEXT:

BREXIT DATE: In the event the deal passes, Brexit date will be moved to 22nd May as agreed with the European Commission in Strasbourg. If not, the date remains as April 12th. (See below for possible scenarios). BBC's Katya Adler noted that if UK chooses no deal, EU very unlikely to insist 12 April date to leave. It will likely choose 22 May as cut off date. This still separates Brexit from European Parliamentary elections (they start 23 May) but leaves extra time to better finalise no deal preparations. 

GENERAL ELECTION: UK government ministers privately suggested a general election will be called if Friday's vote is rejected or things "fall apart", according HuffPost's Paul Waugh

content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European Indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.5%] are higher continuing the positive momentum from Asia – Of note, all of the Big 4 Chinese banks have now reported
  • House of Commons vote on the Withdrawal Agreement 14:30GMT/10:30EDT; no amendments have been selected for debate in Parliament
  • Dollar remains firm, but has lost some momentum against G10 counterparts while cable is somewhat depressed ahead of todays vote.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US PCE Price Index, Canadian GDP, Fed's Williams & Quarles, HoC to vote on the Withdrawal Agreement, US-China trade talks continue in Beijing

 

ASIA  

Asian equity markets were higher across the board as the region took impetus from the US, where all major indices finished positive and trade-sensitive sectors outperformed on optimism as US-China high-level talks resumed in Beijing. ASX 200 (+0.1%) eked mild gain as most sectors remained afloat heading into quarter-end although gold miners were heavily weighed after the precious metal succumbed to the pressure from a firmer greenback. Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was driven by currency weakness with Daiichi Sankyo surging nearly 16% to hit limit up and a record high after it signed a USD 6.9bln collaboration and commercialization deal for its cancer drug with AstraZeneca in which it will receive an upfront payment of USD 1.35bln. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) conformed to the upbeat tone and the Shanghai Comp. (+3.2%) outperformed as trade discussions continued in Beijing and after China announced electricity and fuel costs reductions ahead of incoming VAT cuts. Huawei also supported the risk appetite after it posted a 25% increase in annual profits despite the ongoing US tiff, although not all stocks benefitted as some contended with disappointing earnings including China’s largest lender ICBC which fell short of FY net forecasts after flat Q4 profits. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as the fixed income complex eased from the rampant inflows seen this week and as gains in stocks dampened demand for safe-haven assets, although downside was limited with the BoJ also in the market for JPY 710bln of JGBs in the belly to super long-end.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 110bln vs. Prev. CNY 90bln net injection W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7335 (Prev. 6.7263)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin commented that they had a productive working dinner last night in Beijing and was looking forward to today. (Newswires) Japanese Tokyo CPI (Mar) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.9%    (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires) Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Mar) Y/Y 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%) Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Mar) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

Agricultural Bank of China (1288 HK) FY18 net profit CNY 202.78bln. Net interest margin at 2.33%. Non-performing loan ratio of 1.59%, at the end of December. (Newswires)

Bank of China (3988 HK) reports FY net CNY 180.1bln vs. Exp. CNY 1.75.6bln, NPL ratio 1.42% at end-2018, CET1 ratio 11.41%. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed's Bullard (voter, dove) said normalization process in US is at an end and suggested they have gone as far as they can. Bullard also commented that it is premature to consider a rate cut now and that he sees a likely rebound in economic growth during Q2 and the rest of 2019. (Newswires)

Canada is considering a new tariff retaliation to end US tariff tussle, according to sources cited by CBC. (CBC)

UK/EU   

UK House of Commons speaker selects no amendments for debate today. (Newswires)

UK government source confirmed they were laying a motion to give MPs a vote on the withdrawal agreement only for Friday without the political declaration on the future relationship between the EU and the UK, while a government source said the vote to approve the withdrawal agreement would meet the EU's test to extend A50 to May 22nd and is said to be substantially different to MV3. (Newswires/BBC/Twitter)

UK government ministers privately suggested a general election will be called if Friday's vote is rejected or things "fall apart", according HuffPost's Paul Waugh. Elsewhere, there were comments from House Speaker Bercow that the new government motion meets his tests and only covers withdrawal agreement, while Sun's Tom Newton Dunn reports it will occur at 14:30GMT/10:30EDT. (Newswires/Twitter/Huffington Post)

UK opposition Labour leader Corbyn told PM May he will not be voting in favour of the WA today, while DUP Deputy Leader Dodds said the DUP will not back the WA and that a softer form of Brexit is now possible but added the DUP's priority is ensuring no barriers between Northern Ireland and rest of UK instead of the form of Brexit. Furthermore, reports state that around 20 hard-line Tory Eurosceptics still oppose the deal. Separately, UK MPs claim that just 12 hardcore Tory ERG MPs are left opposing PM May's deal; according to Sun's Deputy Political Editor Steve Hawkes. (Newswires/Telegraph/Twitter)

EU will insist that Britain pays a GBP 39bln divorce bill and implements the Irish backstop before beginning emergency talks to prevent an economic crash in the event of a no-deal Brexit. Furthermore, there were also reports that Britain faces staying in the EU another year if the withdrawal agreement is voted down today. (Times)

At least 10 cabinet ministers are considering putting themselves forward as PM May's replacement following her promise to step down if her Brexit deal goes through. (Newswires)

Hard Brexiteers who are now backing PM May's deal, believe that those Tories who are holding out are now in the 'mid-teens', as well as 6 remainers., Sky's Cohen. (Twitter)  A UK Minister reportedly believes that PM May's WA will be voted down by 20 votes; according to Mail on Sunday's Deputy Political Editor Cole. (Twitter)

There is little expectation in the EU today that the Withdrawal Agreement will pass and as such, the EU mood is one of resignation now, according to BBC's Adler. (Twitter) SNP's Gray says some Labour MP's are preparing to back PM May's agreement. (Newswires)

ECB's Visco says that rates are expected to remain at the current level at least until the end of 2019, and then for as long as necessary. Adds that inflation converging towards the 2% goal is being pursued will all the available instruments. (Newswires)

ECB's Coeure (Neutral) says a marked fall in the inflation risk premium suggests investors only assign a small probability to inflation turning out to be greater than expected. (Newswires)

French CPI (EU Norm) Prelim YY Mar 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.6%)

EQUITIES

A relatively upbeat start for European equities [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.5%] following on from a stellar performance in Asia, wherein the Shanghai Composite ended the week higher in excess of 3% as US-Sino talks concluded on a seemingly positive note. Broad based gains are seen across major indices, UK’s FTSE (+0.5%) is keeping its composure amid the Brexit-induced weakness in the Sterling and as heavyweight mining names benefit from the surge in base metal prices: [Antofagasta (+2.6%), Glencore (+2.4%), Anglo American (+2.1%) and Rio Tinto (+2.0%)]. Sector-wise, material names lead the gains, whilst consumer discretionary names benefit from positive broker moves for Kering (+1.4%), LVMH (+1.2%) and Richemont (+0.9%). Looking at individual movers, Wirecard (-6.9%) shares plumb the depths following yet another FT article which noted that half the company’s revenues come from partners whilst noting that at some of them there is a mismatch with reality on the ground. A Wirecard executive has noted the article in incorrect and misleading. Elsewhere, yet more trouble for Scandi banks with Swedbank (-9.5%), Nordea Bank (-9.8%) lower after New York regulators reportedly expanded money laundering scandal probe into Nordea Bank.

FX

USD - The Greenback remains firm overall, but has lost a bit of momentum against a few G10 and other counterparts at the start of the final trading session of the week, month and quarter as latest US-China trade talk reports suggest more progress made. However, the DXY has nudged above the 97.300 level that capped its advances yesterday and in doing so crossed a key Fib at 97.245 (76.4% retrace of the fall from 97.711 to 95.735), which bodes well from a chart standpoint ahead of potentially pivotal data including Chicago PMI and a trio of Fed speakers (Williams, Kaplan and Quarles).

NZD/AUD/CAD - Bucking the broad trend on the aforementioned constructive US-China vibes, but with the Kiwi also getting a much needed fillip from ANZ’s consumer sentiment survey overnight showing an improvement in March. Nzd/Usd rebounded to just over 0.6800 at one stage, but then pared gains on more dovish RBNZ impulses, albeit indirectly as JPM updated its 2019 outlook for NZ rates with back-to-back cuts now seen in May and June. Similar story for the Aussie that briefly reclaimed 0.7100 before fading, while the Loonie is still relatively rangebound between 1.3420-45 ahead of Canadian PPI data.

JPY/EUR/CHF/GBP - All softer vs the Usd, with the Jpy extending its retreat from a fraction shy of 110.00 to circa 110.92 amidst reports of Japanese selling for FY end on top of the general improvement in risk sentiment. However, supply is said to be sitting at 111.00 and the recent 110.96 peak is still providing technical resistance. The single currency is holding just above 1.1200 with buying interest touted from 1.1210 down to the figure and decent option expiry interest also supporting as 1.5 bn rolls off at the NY cut vs 1.2 bn from 1.1250-60. The Franc is essentially flat vs the Buck and Euro around 0.9950 and within 1.1190-65 parameters respectively following SNB comments on Thursday reinforcing the commitment to maintain NIRP and intervention given the Chf’s ongoing high valuation and fragility in the currency markets. Last, but by no means least heading into yet another crucial Brexit vote in the HoC, the Pound is depressed with Cable almost losing the 1.3000 handle despite a big buy order at 1.3010 and Eur/Gbp pivoting 0.8600 where a sizeable 1 bn expiries reside and run-off only 30 minutes or so before the Parliament decide whether to back the WA.

EM - In contrast to partial recoveries elsewhere, the Lira has lurched to new lows vs the Dollar not far from 5.6600 as the run continues almost relentlessly, and with little last respite from a narrower than forecast Turkish trade deficit.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts and Short Sterling contracts have rebounded relatively firmly from yesterday’s closes after opening mark-ups and a few early wobbles to stretch their advances relative to Eurozone and US counterparts. The 10 year benchmark is sitting towards the upper end of its 129.40-61 Liffe range vs Thursday’s 129.28 settlement and the 3 month strip is 1-1.5 ticks ahead compared to +2.5 ticks at best, awaiting multiple UK data releases at 9.30GMT, but actually setting stalls out for the latest chapter in the Brexit saga in the form of Parliament’s debate and vote on the WA. Back to Bunds, the 10-year German debt future remains mid-range between 166.13-41 following further encouraging German data in comparison to the disappointments earlier in the month, and as eurozone peripheral bonds trade firmer into month end (recall, some month-end indices show a lengthy extension for marginal debt). Turning to US treasuries, the curve is steeper and futures are weaker ahead of a busy Friday data schedule and 3 Fed speakers.

COMMODITIES

WTI (+0.8%) and Brent (+0.6%) futures are on the front foot thus far amid the overall positive risk sentiment around the market as US-China talks are to continue next week after concluding in Beijung on a positive note. WTI futures extended gains above USD 59.00/bbl and remain in relatively close proximity to USD 60.00/bbl whilst Brent futures reside around USD 67.50/bbl. In the month of March, Brent Crude advanced around 1.6% whilst WTI crude posted gains in excess of 4%. In terms of recent energy news-flow Russian Energy Minister denied the report that Russia will only agree to extend output cut deal by 3 months and said Russia and Iran potential extension of OPEC+ deal. This follows source reports yesterday that OPEC and Russia could agree to a 3-month extension of the current agreement at the June meeting. Elsewhere, Gold ekes mild gains following yesterday’s slump below USD 1300/oz. Meanwhile, copper and iron are extending on earlier gains as optimism surrounding trade talks bolster the base metals.

Russia Energy Minister denies report that Russia will only agree to extend output cut deal by 3 months and said Russia and Iran potential extension of OPEC+ deal. (Newswires) This follows source reports yesterday that OPEC and Russian could agree to a 3-month extension of the current agreement at the June meeting.

Barclays say that Brent prices are likely to move higher in Q2, average USD 73/bbl, with WTI to average USD 65/bbl. Expects global oil demand is to grow by 1.3mln BPD this year. Prices are unlikely to exceed USD 75/bbl for more than a quarter. (Newswires)

China Q2 copper treatment and refining costs floor was lowered to USD 73/ton vs. Prev. USD 92/ton Q/Q. In addition, China is to reduce electricity tariffs for industrial and commercial use, as well as lower retail prices of gasoline by CNY 225/ton and diesel by CNY 200/ton from April 1st due to VAT cuts. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto declared a force majeure on some iron ore shipments and is assessing damage at its Cape Lambert port in Western Australia. (Newswires)

subject: UK House of Commons speaker selects no amendments for debate today
analysis_details:
These amendments would have been:

  • (A) – MACNEIL/CLARKE/WEST/ VAZ/EDWARDS/WISHART: Calls on the government to bring forward urgently the legislation necessary to require the Prime Minister to revoke Article 50 before Brexit day.
  • (B) – SNELL/NANDY/FIELD/LEWIS/FLINT/COOPER: Approves Withdrawal Agreement but gives MPs more say on future relationship with the EU. Also require the PM to report on progress every three months.
  • (C) – BLACKFORD/BLACKMAN/ROBERTS/GRANT/GETHINS/GRADY: The government cannot leave the EU without the agreement of the Scottish parliament and the Welsh Assembly

subject: Bunds: retaining an underlying bid into month and quarter end
content: The core Eurozone bond continues to consolidate off Wednesday’s elevated highs, but appears to have survived test of bids ahead of the 166.00 handle and some selling in wake of much better than expected German retail sales data. However, a fleeting uptick above yesterday’s 166.39 close was quickly faded amidst a rebound in EU stocks on the back of gains across Asia-Pacific bourses and positive vibes emanating from the latest US-China trade talks. Bunds remain off worst levels (166.13) as March and Q1 draws to a close, with the next fundamental input coming via German unemployment before more Eurozone inflation data, this time from Italy. Comments from ECB’s Coeure will also be monitored for anything on TLTRO3 and/or the potential for a tiered deposit system to be adopted that was poo pooed by Knot on Thursday.

RPC (RPC LN) – Co. and Berry Global have updated on anti-trust clearance, waiting period has expired. (Newswires)

Salini Impregilo (SAL IM) – Awarded a EUR 608.1mln contract for the construction of a high-capacity raillroad between Bari and Naples. Co., along with Astaldi (AST IM), are to build the Aprice-Hirprinia section of the line. For reference the Co. have a 60% stake in the consortium. (Newswires)

Micro Focus (MCRO LN) – Co. reiterate guidance which was provided with prelim results on 14th Feb. (Newswires)

Nexi – Italian market watchdog Consob has provided approval for the Nexi IPO, to run from March 29th to April 11th. Expected to debut on Milan stock market on 16th April. For reference, Nexi the Italian payment Co. has been valued at up to EUR 6.4bln, making it one of Europe’s largest listings this year.

Altice (ATC NA) – FY revenue EUR 14.1bln, -2.9%.  Co. state their FY18 guidance was achieved,  generated a FY operating free cash flow of EUR 2.36bln; in-line with guidance. Co. are reportedly to use deals in order to help them reduce leverage. (Newswires)

BASF (BAS GY)/Covestro (1COV GY) - DowDuPont (DWDP) sees lower Q1 net sales in which it expects a decline by high single-digit percentage. (Newswires)

EssilorLuxottica (EL FP) – Essilor say they are ready to accept arbitration with Luxottica, according to Stampa. (Newswires)

Nestle (NESN SW) – Federal judge has rejected the Co’s attempts to dismiss a lawsuit which alleges that the Co. filled bottles of their Poland spring water with ordinary water. (Newswires)

TUI (TUI1 GY) -  Co. say they have secured additional flight capacity in order to guarantee customers demand, add that a further 8 737 Max are scheduled for delivery by the end of May 2019. Co. have cut their 2019 guidance. (Newswires)

SSE (SSE LN) - Co. have announced a GBP 50mln share buyback programme, as part of the Co's capital return programme which was announced on 1st Feb 2019. (Newswires)

A.P. Moller-Maersk (MAERSKB DC) - Co. say they are no longer seeking the seperation for Maersk supply service. (Newswires)

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

29th March 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were higher across the board as the region took impetus from the US, where all major indices finished positive and trade-sensitive sectors outperformed on optimism as US-China high-level talks resumed in Beijing. ASX 200 (+0.1%) eked mild gain as most sectors remained afloat heading into quarter-end although gold miners were heavily weighed after the precious metal succumbed to the pressure from a firmer greenback. Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was driven by currency weakness with Daiichi Sankyo surging nearly 16% to hit limit up and a record high after it signed a USD 6.9bln collaboration and commercialization deal for its cancer drug with AstraZeneca in which it will receive an upfront payment of USD 1.35bln. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) conformed to the upbeat tone and the Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) outperformed as trade discussions continued in Beijing and after China announced electricity and fuel costs reductions ahead of incoming VAT cuts. Huawei also supported the risk appetite after it posted a 25% increase in annual profits despite the ongoing US tiff, although not all stocks benefitted as some contended with disappointing earnings including China’s largest lender ICBC which fell short of FY net forecasts after flat Q4 profits.

FTSE

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) – Co. have announced a global development and commercialisation agreement with Daiichi Sankyo (4568 JT), Co. are to pay a consideration of up to USD 6.9bln, which includes a USD 1.35bln upfront payment. Co. are to partially fund this deal through a USD 3.5bln share sale. (Newswires/FT) Daiichi Sankyo shares were around 16% higher overnight on this agreement.

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Co. are to create a ‘white list’ of publishers for use in their online marketing campaigns, as the Co. wished to exert more control over where their ads are placed due to the growing scepticism which surrounds digital marketing. (Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

MAN GROUP (EMG LN) INITIATED WITH OUTPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

DAX

Defence Names – German Government have stated they will extend the ban on exporting arms to Saudi Arabia for an additional 6-months. (Newswires)

Daimler (DAI GY) – CEO stated the production site in Hambach, France will continue to produce a electric smart car, following the announced joint venture with Geely, with the new site in China allowing expansion. Joint venture have stated that the new smart-cars will be built in 2022. (FT)

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – US States are investigating the potential merger between T-Mobile & Sprint Corp, are considering a lawsuit which would block the deal on antitrust grounds; even in the scenario that the Justice Department approve the deal. (Newswires)

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 29th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click hereIf you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets were higher across the board, Shanghai Composite outperformed as US-China trade talks are underway
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that US and Chinese negotiators had a productive working dinner last night in Beijing
  • UK House Speaker accepted a vote on the Withdrawal Agreement for today at around 1430GMT/1030EDT; Labour and DUP parties are set to vote against it
  • In FX markets, the DXY held steady above the 97.00 level following the prior day’s advances heading into month end and quarter end
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German Retail Sales & Unemployment Data, UK GDP, US PCE Price Index, Canadian GDP, Fed's Williams & Quarles, ECB's Coeure, HoC to vote on the Withdrawal Agreement, US-China trade talks continue in Beijing

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were higher across the board as the region took impetus from the US, where all major indices finished positive and trade-sensitive sectors outperformed on optimism as US-China high-level talks resumed in Beijing. ASX 200 (+0.1%) eked mild gain as most sectors remained afloat heading into quarter-end although gold miners were heavily weighed after the precious metal succumbed to the pressure from a firmer greenback. Nikkei 225 (+0.8%) was driven by currency weakness with Daiichi Sankyo surging nearly 16% to hit limit up and a record high after it signed a USD 6.9bln collaboration and commercialization deal for its cancer drug with AstraZeneca in which it will receive an upfront payment of USD 1.35bln. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) conformed to the upbeat tone and the Shanghai Comp. (+2.6%) outperformed as trade discussions continued in Beijing and after China announced electricity and fuel costs reductions ahead of incoming VAT cuts. Huawei also supported the risk appetite after it posted a 25% increase in annual profits despite the ongoing US tiff, although not all stocks benefitted as some contended with disappointing earnings including China’s largest lender ICBC which fell short of FY net forecasts after flat Q4 profits. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower as the fixed income complex eased from the rampant inflows seen this week and as gains in stocks dampened demand for safe-haven assets, although downside was limited with the BoJ also in the market for JPY 710bln of JGBs in the belly to super long-end.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 110bln vs. Prev. CNY 90bln net injection W/W. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7335 (Prev. 6.7263)

US President Trump said US is doing well with China in trade talks and other countries. Elsewhere, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin commented that they had a productive working dinner last night in Beijing and was looking forward to today. (Newswires) Japanese Tokyo CPI (Mar) Y/Y 0.9% vs. Exp. 0.9%    (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires) Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food (Mar) Y/Y 1.1% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.1%) Japanese Tokyo CPI Ex. Fresh Food & Energy (Mar) Y/Y 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 0.7%)

UK/EU

UK government source confirmed they were laying a motion to give MPs a vote on the withdrawal agreement only for Friday without the political declaration on the future relationship between the EU and the UK, while a government source said the vote to approve the withdrawal agreement would meet the EU's test to extend A50 to May 22nd and is said to be substantially different to MV3. (Newswires/BBC/Twitter)

UK government ministers privately suggested a general election will be called if Friday's vote is rejected or things "fall apart", according HuffPost's Paul Waugh. Elsewhere, there were comments from House Speaker Bercow that the new government motion meets his tests and only covers withdrawal agreement, while Sun's Tom Newton Dunn reports it will occur at 14:30GMT/10:30EDT. (Newswires/Twitter/Huffington Post)

UK opposition Labour leader Corbyn told PM May he will not be voting in favour of the WA today, while DUP Deputy Leader Dodds said the DUP will not back the WA and that a softer form of Brexit is now possible but added the DUP's priority is ensuring no barriers between Northern Ireland and rest of UK instead of the form of Brexit. Furthermore, reports state that around 20 hard-line Tory Eurosceptics still oppose the deal. (Newswires/Telegraph)

EU will insist that Britain pays a GBP 39bln divorce bill and implements the Irish backstop before beginning emergency talks to prevent an economic crash in the event of a no-deal Brexit. Furthermore, there were also reports that Britain faces staying in the EU another year if the withdrawal agreement is voted down today. (Times)

At least 10 cabinet ministers are considering putting themselves forward as PM May's replacement following her promise to step down if her Brexit deal goes through. (Newswires)

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Mar) -13 vs. Exp. -14.0 (Prev. -13.0). (Newswires) UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Mar) 10 (Prev. 4)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY held steady above the 97.00 level following the prior day’s advances and as its main counterparts remained subdued including EUR/USD which languished near 2-week lows as some suggested the ECB’s consideration of tiered-deposit rates could be an intention to keep rates lower for longer. Meanwhile, GBP/USD composed itself following the Brexit-related bedlam and ahead of today’s watered-down vote in which MPs will decide on the withdrawal agreement only, and not the political declaration on the future relationship with the EU, to secure a Brexit date extension. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses benefitted from safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans were somewhat choppy as support from the heightened risk appetite was counterbalanced by the dovish views for their central banks with JP Morgan now forecasting the RBNZ to lower rates in May and June this year, and as some suggested potential ramifications this could have for the RBA ahead of next week’s policy meeting.

RBNZ Governor Orr commented on the market reaction to the recent policy review in which he is said to be pleased markets have shown they understand what the central bank is focused on, while he also commented that the bank’s easing bias is a starting point for the incoming MPC. (Newswires)

SNB's Maechler said CHF remains highly valued and currency remains fragile, while Maechler added that negative rates and currency interventions remains necessary where required. (Newswires) 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures were supported by the risk appetite and following the prior day’s rebound through the USD 59.00/bbl level, although the gains were mild amid mixed news flow including Mexico ports reopening and the US further tightening the noose on Venezuela. Elsewhere, gold prices remained subdued after it recently gave up the USD 1300/oz due to the stronger greenback, while copper benefitted from the elevated risk appetite and outperformance in China.

Russia Energy Minister denies report that Russia will only agree to extend output cut deal by 3 months and said Russia and Iran potential extension of OPEC+ deal. (Newswires) This follows source reports yesterday that OPEC and Russian could agree to a 3-month extension of the current agreement at the June meeting.

US instructed foreign trading firms and refiners to stop direct and indirect oil swap deals with Venezuela and warned a continuation would be seen as a sanction breach according to sources. Furthermore, reports added that only deliveries of jet fuel and diesel can continue for humanitarian reasons, while the US government reportedly asked OPEC behind closed doors to remove Venezuelan official from OPEC presidency. (Newswires)

US President Trump is to issue an Executive Order to speed up pipeline development. (Axios)

China Q2 copper treatment and refining costs floor was lowered to USD 73/ton vs. Prev. USD 92/ton Q/Q. In addition, China is to reduce electricity tariffs for industrial and commercial use, as well as lower retail prices of gasoline by CNY 225/ton and diesel by CNY 200/ton from April 1st due to VAT cuts. (Newswires)

CME lowered May 2019 NYMEX crude oil futures margins by 8.1% to USD 3400 per contract and raised NYMEX palladium futures margins by 25% to USD 10313 per contract. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto declared a force majeure on some iron ore shipments and is assessing damage at its Cape Lambert port in Western Australia. (Newswires)

US

The curve was mixed at settlement, with 2s5s a touch steeper, though other major curve spreads narrowed (5s30s by as much as 5bps). There was optimism about US/China trade talks, which saw some flattening in European trade. Treasuries took some influence from the Bund after German inflation was short of expectations. There was little reaction after data showed US GDP in Q4 was revised lower. The Treasury's 7s auction was decent, stopping through by 0.9bps, with cover above recent averages; there was reported short-covering after the auction. Fed's Williams -- like the Fed's Daly earlier in the week -- suggested that the yield curve inversion might not necessarily portend a recession; previously some FOMC members have argued that the size of the Fed's balance sheet makes presents challenges for this signal as portending a recession. US T-note futures (M9) settled 6 ticks lower at 124-16.

Fed's Bullard (voter, dove) said normalization process in US is at an end and suggested they have gone as far as they can. Bullard also commented that it is premature to consider a rate cut now and that he sees a likely rebound in economic growth during Q2 and the rest of 2019. (Newswires)

Fed's Williams (voter, hawk) said the US economy is in a very good place and there is a reality it is slowing but to a sustainable pace. Williams also commented that he is not as worried about the chances of a recession as some in the private sector and that yield curve inversion has historically pointed to a recession but that may not be the case today, while he also doesn't believe governments can run large deficits indefinitely without consequences. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks gain across the board and China surges amid trade talks and VAT cuts
content:
Asia equity markets are higher across the board as the region takes impetus from the US, where all major indices finished positive and trade-sensitive sectors outperformed on optimism as US-China talks resumed. ASX 200 (+0.3%) has eked mild gain as most sectors remain afloat heading into quarter-end aside from gold miners after the precious metal succumbed to the pressure from a firmer greenback, while Nikkei 225 (+1.0%) stocks are driven by currency weakness, as well as news flow with Daiichi Sankyo surging nearly 16% to hit limit up and a record high after it signed a USD 6.9bln collaboration and commercialization deal for its cancer drug with AstraZeneca in which it will receive an upfront payment of USD 1.35bln. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.4%) outperform as high-level trade talks continue in Beijing and with China also announcing electricity and fuel costs reductions due to VAT cuts. However, not all stocks have benefitted as some contend with earnings including China’s largest lender ICBC which fell short of FY net forecasts after flat Q4 profits.

In FX markets, the DXY holds steady above the 97.00 level following the prior day’s advances as its main counterparts remain subdued including EUR/USD which languishes near 2-week lows as some suggest ECB’s consideration of tiered-deposit rates as an intention to keep rates lower for longer. Meanwhile, GBP/USD attempts some composure following the Brexit-related bedlam and ahead of today’s watered-down Brexit vote in which MPs will vote on the withdrawal agreement only, and not the political declaration on the future relationship with the EU, to secure a Brexit date extension. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses benefit from safe-haven outflows, while antipodeans are somewhat choppy with support from the heightened risk appetite counterbalanced by the dovish views for the relevant central banks with JP Morgan now forecasting the RBNZ to lower rates in May and June this year, and as some also suggest potential ramifications this could have for the RBA ahead of next week’s policy meeting.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as the fixed income complex begins to ease from the rampant inflows this week and as gains in stocks dampen demand for safe-haven assets, although downside is limited with the BoJ also in the market for JPY 710bln of JGBs in the belly to super long-end.
